misconceptions.name: Reading wrong number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers as required, the program reads 3 double values representing velocities and time, using a prompt from a different problem. This means it never even attempts to gather the correct data for summing 5 integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse this acceleration-calculator style input (v0, v1, t as doubles) for this task, and that is sufficient for the current problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., using nextInt()), with a prompt that matches the task. The values should represent the 5 integers to be checked and summed, not unrelated quantities like velocities or time.
symptoms: Prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Program only calls nextDouble() three times.
No use of integer input methods such as nextInt() for the 5 required integers.
The data read cannot be used to compute the sum of 5 even integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copy-paste or reuse of code from a different physics-related problem (average acceleration), without adapting the input-handling logic to the new specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three double inputs with a loop or repeated nextInt() calls to read 5 integers from the user. Update the prompt to something like "Enter 5 integers:" and store those integer values for further processing.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, prompt string, and use of three nextDouble() calls match an acceleration-calculation problem, not the specified task of reading 5 integers.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, and t instead of five integers required for the sum-of-even-numbers task.

misconceptions.name: No loop to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple user inputs. It reads three values once and then uses a single hard-coded integer value (5) instead of iterating over 5 user-provided integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can handle this problem without a loop by working with a single value (here, a hard-coded 5) or just the few values I already read.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process 5 integers from the user, a loop (such as a for- or while-loop) should iterate 5 times, reading one integer on each iteration and updating the sum accordingly.
symptoms: No for, while, or do-while loops present.
Only a single integer variable num is declared and set to 5.
No repeated reading or processing of 5 separate values.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misunderstanding of the requirement to handle multiple inputs using iteration, or reliance on a previously written single-calculation template.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop that runs 5 times. Inside the loop, read an integer from the user and conditionally add it to the running sum. Remove the hard-coded num = 5.
related_concepts: Iterating over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no loop constructs and only one integer num, which is not read from input, showing the student did not attempt iterative processing.

evidence.note: The only integer involved in the supposed summing logic is a single hard-coded num = 5, with no loop around it.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number conditional check
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0). As a result, there is no logic to filter out odd numbers; the code does not implement the required even-number condition at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: Either I do not need to check which numbers are even, or I have not yet considered how to implement the even-number condition for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only the even numbers, each input integer must be tested with a condition like if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the sum. Only numbers passing this test should contribute to the sum.
symptoms: No occurrences of the modulus operator (%) in the code.
No if-statement or boolean check related to evenness.
The supposed summing step attempts to use a fixed value (5) without testing if it is even.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have focused on another task (average acceleration) and never integrated the conditional logic specific to even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, add an if-statement: if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }. Review how the modulus operator works for determining even and odd numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: A search of the code shows no use of %, no if-conditions tied to numeric parity, and no other mechanism that could represent an even-number filter.

evidence.note: The only attempted summing logic does not include any condition to check if a number is even; there is no use of n % 2 == 0 anywhere in the file.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of println return value in accumulation
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to add the result of System.out.println(num) to an integer sum, implying they believe println produces a numeric value that can be added. In Java, println returns void, so it cannot be used as an expression in arithmetic operations.
misconceptions.student_belief: System.out.println(num) produces a numeric result (perhaps the printed value) that can be added to sum using sum += System.out.println(num).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: System.out.println is a void method: it performs an action (printing) but does not return any value. Void methods cannot be used in expressions like sum += ... . To accumulate, use sum += num; and call System.out.println(num); separately if you want to display the value.
symptoms: Use of sum += System.out.println(num); which is not valid Java.
The code will not compile because a void value cannot be used in an arithmetic expression.
No correct accumulation of integer values into sum, and no correct printing of the final sum.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between the side effect of printing and the concept of a return value, and misunderstanding of how method return types (void vs numeric) interact with expressions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Separate printing from calculation. First update the sum with sum += num; then, if needed, print the sum or the current number in a separate System.out.println(...) statement. Review the idea of method return types and void methods in Java.
related_concepts: Using expressions vs statements in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The exact expression sum += System.out.println(num); is a strong, unambiguous indicator that the student expects println to produce a numeric value usable in arithmetic.

evidence.note: This line incorrectly treats System.out.println(num) as if it returned an int that could be added to sum.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: The final print statement outputs average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers, indicating further misunderstanding of what result should be accumulated and displayed.

misconceptions.task: Reading 5 integers from input, Loop structure to process inputs, Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0), Accumulating sum and printing result

misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (likely from a different problem) instead of the required task of reading five integers and calculating the sum of only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for an entirely different assignment, failing to address any of the requirements for 'Sum of Even Numbers'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read five separate integer inputs, use a loop, and apply conditional logic (modulo operator) to filter and sum only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Code calculates acceleration using a physics formula
No loop or conditional logic is present related to the actual problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misunderstanding of the assignment or submitting code intended for a different question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code matches the prompt for the current question (Q1). The code must implement input reading for 5 integers, looping, and filtering based on even/odd status.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code structure and logic (reading v0, v1, t and calculating acceleration) confirm it is solving a different physics problem.

evidence.note: The class name and the input/calculation logic are entirely focused on solving an acceleration problem, not finding the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misuse of void Method in Arithmetic Expression
misconceptions.description: The student attempted to use the return value of the `System.out.println()` method, which is `void` (returns nothing), in an arithmetic operation (`sum += ...`). This is a critical compilation error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that an output function like `System.out.println()` must return the value it just printed, and this returned value can be legally used in accumulating a sum.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: `System.out.println()` performs an action (printing) but returns nothing (`void`). If a value needs to be used in an expression, it must come from a variable or a method that returns a non-void type.
symptoms: Code will not compile due to incompatible types ('void' cannot be converted to 'int')
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion regarding the purpose and signature (return type) of standard library methods.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Methods that are declared 'void' cannot be used on the right-hand side of an assignment or arithmetic operation. If you intended to reset the sum, use simple assignment (`sum = ...`); if you intended to add the number 5, use `sum += 5;`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The line `sum += System.out.println(num);` is a classic example of this specific conceptual error.

evidence.note: Attempting to add the 'void' result of println to an integer variable 'sum'.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding void method return values
misconceptions.description: Student attempts to assign the return value of System.out.println() (a void method) to a variable in an accumulation operation. This reflects a misunderstanding that void methods do not return values and cannot be used in expressions or assignments.
misconceptions.student_belief: System.out.println() returns a value that can be accumulated with += operator
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, void methods do not return any value. System.out.println() prints to the console but returns nothing. It cannot be used on the right side of an assignment or in arithmetic/accumulation operations.
symptoms: Code will not compile; compilation error on the line with sum += System.out.println()
Attempted to mix printing and accumulation in a single statement
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about Java method return types and the meaning of the void keyword. Student may not understand that void methods perform side effects (like printing) but do not evaluate to a value.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Separate the operations: first read/store the value, then check if it's even, then accumulate it into sum. Use a println() statement separately after the loop to print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The syntax error is explicit and unambiguous. The code line sum += System.out.println(num) is invalid Java and will not compile. This is a clear semantic misconception about void methods.

evidence.note: Student attempts to accumulate the return value of System.out.println(), which is a void method. This line will not compile because void cannot be used in this context.

Only a single hardcoded value (5) is used

misconceptions.name: Missing even/odd conditional logic
misconceptions.description: The code contains no conditional statement to check if a number is even (using modulo operator %). This is the core logic required to filter only even numbers for the sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: No explicit even/odd checking is necessary; perhaps all numbers should be summed or only one value processed
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The core requirement of Q1 is to filter even numbers using the condition (num % 2 == 0) before adding them to the sum. This requires an if statement inside the loop.
symptoms: No if statement checking for even numbers
No modulo (%) operator used
No filtering logic in the code

evidence.note: The section that should contain the main Q1 logic has no if statement, no modulo operation, and no filtering logic for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Using println as if it returns a numeric value
misconceptions.description: The student tries to add the result of System.out.println(num) to an integer accumulator, which suggests they believe println produces a numeric value that can be used in expressions.
misconceptions.student_belief: System.out.println(num) evaluates to a numeric value (probably the number printed) that can be added to sum.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: System.out.println is a void method; it performs a side effect (printing to the console) and does not return any value. You cannot use it in arithmetic expressions. To accumulate a sum, you must add the variable directly (e.g., sum += num;) and then optionally print separately.
symptoms: Line attempting sum += System.out.println(num); causes a compile-time error because a void method is used in an expression.
Even if it compiled, this line would not correctly update the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between methods that return values and methods that only have side effects; the student treats a void-printing method as if it were a value-returning function.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Separate computation from output. First update the accumulator with a numeric expression, e.g., sum += num; then call System.out.println(num); on its own line if you want to display it. Review the difference between void methods and methods that return a value.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses sum += System.out.println(num); which only makes sense if the student believes println yields a value; this is not a typo like a missing semicolon.

evidence.note: Uses System.out.println(num) inside an arithmetic expression, indicating misunderstanding of println's void return type.

misconceptions.name: Misuse of System.out.println in accumulation
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to add the result of `System.out.println(num)` to the `sum` variable. Since `System.out.println` returns `void` (nothing), this code is a syntax error in Java and would prevent compilation. This indicates a misunderstanding of function return types and basic accumulation operations.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `System.out.println(num)` returns the value that was successfully printed (in this case, 5), allowing it to be added to the accumulator `sum`.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, standard output methods (`System.out.print`, `System.out.println`) return `void` and cannot be used as operands in arithmetic expressions or assignments. To add a value, only the variable itself should be used (`sum += num;`).
symptoms: Code fails to compile due to attempting to assign a 'void' return type
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between displaying output (a side effect) and returning a value (a function result).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remember that `System.out.println()` is used only for displaying data to the console and does not give calculated results back to the program. If you want to add the value of 'num' to 'sum', simply write `sum += num;` or `sum = sum + num;`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as this is a fundamental Java error regarding `void` functions attempting to be used in arithmetic expressions.

evidence.snippet:
int num = 5;
        sum += System.out.println(num);
evidence.note: Attempting to use the void-returning function System.out.println() as part of arithmetic accumulation, leading to a compilation error.

misconceptions.name: System.out.println() return type misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: Student attempts to use System.out.println() (which returns void) in an arithmetic assignment statement `sum += System.out.println(num)`. This reflects a fundamental misunderstanding of void return types and the distinction between statements and expressions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes System.out.println() returns a numeric value that can be added to an integer variable.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: System.out.println() returns void (nothing). It is a statement that performs output but does not produce a value. It cannot be used in arithmetic expressions or assigned to variables. To accumulate a sum, use: sum += num; (without System.out.println inside the addition).
symptoms: Code line contains: sum += System.out.println(num);
Compilation error: void type not allowed here
Incorrect understanding of method return types
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may be confusing Java methods with mathematical functions that always return values. Likely has not yet internalized the difference between statements (which execute but return nothing) and expressions (which compute and return a value).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Separate the operations: First accumulate the sum with `sum += num;`, then print with `System.out.println(sum);`. Remember: System.out.println() is for OUTPUT only, not for computation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is unmistakably a semantic error. The code explicitly writes `sum += System.out.println(num);`, which is syntactically invalid in Java. The student clearly misunderstands what void methods return.

evidence.note: System.out.println() returns void, not an integer. This line attempts to assign void to int, which is a type mismatch and indicates misunderstanding of return types.

misconceptions.name: Missing loop for processing 5 inputs
misconceptions.description: The student has no loop structure to process 5 integers. Instead, only 3 double values are read via individual scanner calls. A for-loop or while-loop is necessary to efficiently read and process exactly 5 inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that manually declaring separate variables for each input is an acceptable approach, or simply forgot to implement a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process multiple inputs (e.g., 5 integers), use a loop structure such as `for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = scanner.nextInt(); ... }`. This is more efficient, scalable, and is the standard practice for handling repeated input.
symptoms: No for-loop or while-loop in the code
Only 3 values are read instead of 5
No structure to iterate through multiple inputs
Code does not read 5 integers as required

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the input reading in a loop: `for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = scanner.nextInt(); /* check if even and add to sum */ }`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly lacks any loop structure and only reads 3 inputs. The problem requires 5 integers to be processed. This is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Three separate sequential statements read input, not a loop. No iteration mechanism exists to read 5 integers as required.

No use of the modulo operator `%`
No conditional branching based on even/odd
Cannot filter even numbers from input

evidence.note: No if-statement. No modulo check. No filtering logic whatsoever. The student's accumulation logic does not check whether numbers are even.
